2. Claims against the Individual Officer Defendants  
a.  Applicable Law 
โThe Fourth Amendment protects โ[t]he right of the people to be secure in their persons, 
houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures.โ โ Devenpeck v. Alford, 
543 U.S. 146, 152 (2004) (quoting U.S. Const. amend. IV). A warrantless arrest by a law officer 
69 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 70 of 110
is unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment if โthere is no probable cause to believe that a crime 
has been or is being committed.โ Id. (citations omitted). Probable cause exists when the โtotality 
of the facts and circumstancesโ within an officer's knowledge at the moment of arrest are sufficient 
for a reasonable person to conclude that the suspect had committed or was committing an 
offense.โ Glenn v. City of Tyler, 242 F.3d 307, 313 (5th Cir. 2001) (internal quotation and citation 
omitted). โWhether probable cause exists depends upon the reasonable conclusion to be drawn 
from the facts known to the arresting officer at the time of the arrest.โ Devenpeck, 543 U.S. at 152โ
53 (citations omitted). โ[A]n arresting officer's state of mind (except for the facts that he knows) 
is irrelevant to the existence of probable cause.โ Id., 543 U.S. at 153 (citations omitted). โThat is 
to say, his subjective reason for making the arrest need not be the criminal offense as to which the 
known facts provide probable cause.โ Id., 543 U.S. at 153. 
โTo establish a Fourth Amendment claim for false imprisonment, Plaintiffs must prove: 
(1) an intent by Defendants to confine them, (2) acts resulting in confinement, (3) Plaintiffsโ 
consciousness of confinement or resulting harm, and (4) the deprivation of a constitutional right, 
such as the right not to be arrested or detained without probable cause.โ Allen v. Normand, No. 09-
2825, 2009 WL 2448253, at *13 (E.D. La. Aug. 7, 2009). A plaintiff must establish that the 
defendant's misconduct exceeds mere negligence. Id.; see also, e.g., Sanchez v. Swyden, 139 F.3d 
464,  469  (5th  Cir.  1998)  (actions  must  go  โbeyond  mere  negligenceโ  before  tort  of  false 
imprisonment โtakes on constitutional dimensionsโ; although plaintiff consistently asserted his 
innocence and officers were in possession of exculpatory information, there was โconsiderable 
debateโ about whether plaintiff's appearance matched that of a wanted suspect); Winfrey v. San 
Jacinto  Cty.,  481  F.  App'x  969,  980  (5th  Cir.  2012)  (errors  or  omissions  occasioned  by 
โcarelessness or run-of-the-mill negligenceโ do not state a constitutional claim, although those 
70 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 71 of 110
occasioned by โrecklessnessโ might). โThe โconstitutional tortsโ of false arrest, unreasonable 
seizure, and false imprisonment require a showing of no probable cause.โ Brown v. Lyford, 243 
F.3d 185, 189 (5th Cir. 2001). 
Further, โthe right of criminal defendants to be free from false or fabricated evidence was 
well settled by 1959 or earlierโ. Brown v. Miller, 519 F.3d 231, 237 (5th Cir. 2008).  Thus, for 
example, in Brown, the Fifth Circuit held โthat the deliberate or knowing creation of a misleading 
and scientifically inaccurate serology report amounts to a violation of a defendant's due process 
rights, and that a reasonable laboratory technician in 1984 would have understood that those 
actions violated those rights.โ Id. (finding no error in denial of qualified immunity on this theory). 
Relevant here, under Franks v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154 (1978), โan officer violates the 
Fourth  Amendment  by  intentionally  or  recklessly  including  a  false  statement  in  a  warrant 
application.โ Nerio v. Evans, 974 F.3d 571, 577 (5th Cir. 2020).  โLiability under Franks requires 
a certain mindset and certain conduct: an officer must intentionally, or with a reckless disregard 
for the truth, include a false statement in a warrant application or omit a material fact from it.โ Id. 
(cleaned up).  There is no liability for โan honest mistake.โ Id. (citation omitted). 
b.  Analysis  
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny both motions.  The Court will 
address each motion in turn. 
First, Defendantsโ motion is easily denied.  Again, Plaintiffsโ chart, as verified by the Rule 
30(b)(6) deposition, reflects (1) that Defendants have no evidence that Plaintiffs failed to comply 
with orders or that any Plaintiff engaged in an act of violence, and (2) that, other than the Affidavits 
of Probable Cause (which many times were made without personal knowledge), the City does not 
have any description of any specific Plaintiff's illegal activity. (Rule 30(b)(6) Chart, Doc. 292-1 at 
71 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 72 of 110
1; Rule 30(b)(6) Dep. 26:19โ27:8, 36:21โ37:4, Doc. 292-2; DRPSMF ยถ 12, Doc. 311.)  Moreover, 
the chart also shows that, with a few exceptions, the City had no knowledge of which officer saw 
Plaintiffs commit any crime or of what officer seized Plaintiffs. (Rule 30(b)(6) Dep. 42:21โ43:18, 
45:4โ9, Doc. 292-2.)  A reasonable juror could easily look at this evidence and find that Plaintiffs 
have created questions of fact on the existence of probable cause so as to preclude summary 
judgment in favor of Defendants on the false arrest and imprisonment claims. 
Plaintiffsโ motion is a closer call, but denial is still warranted; while Plaintiffs cite 
considerable evidence supporting a finding of wrongdoing by the police as to the Plaintiffs at issue, 
the Court finds that a reasonable jury could conclude, when construing the evidence in a light most 
favorable to Defendants and drawing reasonable inferences in their favor, that these officers are 
entitled to qualified immunity. 
Plaintiffs cite to the law governing Franks liability generally and the prohibition of 
prophylactically stopping the exercise of First Amendment rights, but Plaintiffs have not provided 
โcontrolling authorityโor a robust consensus of persuasive authorityโthat defines the contours 
of the right in question with a high degree of particularity,โ see McLin, 866 F.3d at 696 (cleaned 
up), for the factual situation as presented by Defendants: where officers executed Affidavits of 
Probable Cause without specific knowledge of the underlying crime but where those officers (1) 
were aware that protests were taking place, (Willie Williams Dep. 16:25โ17:6, 74:7โ75:15, Doc. 
292-24; see also Jonathan Abadie Dep. 11:24โ12:3, 35:8โ22, Doc. 292-7); (2) knew of the โchaos, 
confusion, cutting up,โ and โacts of violenceโ of protesters and their โgoing haywire,โ and knew 
of the protestersโ obstructing traffic at the relevant location, (Willie Williams Dep. 20:14โ23:9, 
74:7โ75:15, Doc. 292-24); (3) then acted on good faith reliance of officers and the information 
provided to them, (Willie Williams Dep. 41:18โ42:9, 46:14โ20, 79:1โ8, Doc. 292-24; Jonathan 
72 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 73 of 110
Abadie Dep. 35:8โ22, 55:1โ7, Doc. 292-7); and (4) did so where there was a risk that the protest 
would venture onto the interstate, thereby endangering the public and preventing the flow of 
traffic, all as detailed above. 
Even if Defendants were wrong or ignorant about these specific nine Plaintiffs, the Court 
cannot  say  that  โthe  law  so  clearly  and  unambiguously  prohibited  [their]  conduct  that 
every reasonable  official  would  understand  that  what  [they  were]  doing  violate[d]  [the 
law].โ McLin, 866 F.3d at 695.  And the Court certainly cannot say that the โrecord is so one-sided 
as to rule out the prospect of the [Defendants] prevailingโ Kane, supra, at ยง 2727.1, or that 
Plaintiffs are entitled to judgment โbeyond peradventure,โ see Fontenot, 780 F.2d at 1194.   
In sum, construing the facts from Defendantsโ perspective (as the Court must do for 
Plaintiffsโ  motion),  Plaintiffs  have  failed  to  provide  โcontrolling  authority  specifically 
prohibit[ing] [ ] [D]efendant[sโ] conductโ so as to overcome qualified immunity. See McLin, 866 
F.3d at 695.  At the very least, a reasonable jury could find in Defendantsโ favor, so Plaintiffsโ 
motion must be denied. 
3. Claims Against the City 
a.  Applicable Law 
โSection 1983 offers no respondeat superior liability.โ Pineda v. City of Houston, 291 F.3d 
325, 328 (5th Cir. 2002). โMunicipalities face ยง 1983 liability โwhen execution of a government's 
policy or custom, whether made by its lawmakers or by those whose edicts or acts may fairly be 
said to represent official policy, inflicts the injury. . . .โ โ Id. (quoting Monell v. Dep't of Soc. Servs. 
of City of New York, 436 U.S. 658, 694 (1978)). That is, โ[a] municipality is liable only for acts 
directly attributable to it โthrough some official action or imprimatur.โ โ Valle v. City of Houston, 
613 F.3d 536, 541 (5th Cir. 2010) (quoting Piotrowski v. City of Houston, 237 F.3d 567, 578 (5th 
73 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 74 of 110
Cir. 2001)). โTo establish municipal liability under ยง 1983, a plaintiff must show the deprivation 
of a federally protected right caused by action taken โpursuant to an official municipal policy.โ 
โ Id. (quoting Monell, 436 U.S. at 691). The Plaintiff must allege โ(1) an official policy (or 
custom), of which (2) a policymaker can be charged with actual or constructive knowledge, and 
(3) a constitutional violation whose โmoving forceโ is that policy or custom.โ Id. at 541โ42 
(cleaned up). 
As to the first two prongs, โ[m]unicipalities can also be liable, in certain situations, for 
single episodes of conduct that are not part of any pattern of illegality.โ Milam v. City of San 
Antonio, 113 F. App'x 622, 626 (5th Cir. 2004) (citing Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Brown, 520 U.S. 
397, 405โ06 (1997) (summarizing the Court's single-episode cases)). โFor example, plaintiffs can 
hold  municipalities  liable  for  single  instances  of  conduct  perpetrated  by  the  policymakers 
themselves;  such  one-time  conduct  can  represent  official  โpolicyโ  even  though  it  does  not 
necessarily form part of a plan or rule developed to govern all like occasions.โ Id. (citing Pembaur 
v. City of Cincinnati, 475 U.S. 469, 480โ81, 484โ85 (1986) (finding that court of appeals erred in 
dismissing petitionerโs claim against a county when the prosecutor, the relevant final policymaker, 
โmade a considered decision based on his understanding of the law and commanded the officers 
forcibly  to  enter  petitionerโs  clinic,โ  and  โ[t]hat  decision  directly  caused  the  violation  of 
petitionerโs Fourth Amendment rights.โ)). 
โThe third prong requires a plaintiff to prove โmoving forceโ causation.โ Valle, 613 F.3d at 
542. โTo succeed, โa plaintiff must show that the municipal action was taken with the requisite 
degree of culpability and must demonstrate a direct causal link between the municipal action and 
the deprivation of federal rights.โ โ Id. (quoting Bd. of the County Comm'rs v. Brown, 520 U.S. 
397, 404 (1997)). โThat is, โthe plaintiff must demonstrate that a municipal decision reflects 
74 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 75 of 110
deliberate indifference to the risk that a violation of a particular constitutional or statutory right 
will follow the decision.โ โ Id. (quoting Brown, 520 U.S. at 411). โDeliberate indifference is a high 
standardโโa  showing  of  simple  or  even  heightened  negligence  will  not  suffice.โ 
โ Id. (quoting Piotrowski, 237 F.3d at 579). 
Additionally, โPlaintiffs must meet a heightened standard of causation in order to hold a 
municipality liable under ยง 1983.โ Id. at 546 (citing City of Canton, Ohio v. Harris, 489 U.S. 378, 
391โ92 (1989)). Plaintiffs must show that the municipal policy was the โ โmoving forceโ that 
caused the specific constitutional violation.โ Id. (citing Brown v. Bryan Cty, Okl., 219 F.3d 450, 
461 (5th Cir. 2000)). โIn other words, the plaintiff must establish a โdirect causal linkโ between the 
municipal policy and the constitutional injury.โ Id. (citing Brown, 520 U.S. at 404). 
โThe Supreme Court has [also] explained that a municipality cannot be liable โ[i]f a person 
has suffered no constitutional injury at the hands of the individual police officer.โ โ Bustos v. 
Martini Club Inc., 599 F.3d 458, 467 (5th Cir. 2010) (quoting City of Los Angeles v. Heller, 475 
U.S. 796, 799 (1986)). Thus, official capacity โclaims fail without an underlying constitutional 
violation.โ Whitley v. Hanna, 726 F.3d 631, 648โ49 (5th Cir. 2013) (citing Bustos, 599 F.3d at 467 
(โBecause [plaintiff] has alleged no constitutional injury attributable to the Officers, [plaintiff] has 
failed  to  state  a  claim  that  a  City  policy  was  the  moving  force  behind  a  violation  of  his 
constitutional rights.โ)).  
Moreover, an authorized policymaker approves a subordinate's decision and the basis for 
it, such ratification is chargeable to the government entity. See City of St. Louis v. Praprotnik, 485 
U.S. 112, 127 (1988). However, the Fifth Circuit has limited the theory of ratification to โextreme 
factual situations.โ Peterson, 588 F.3d 838, 848 (5th Cir. 2009) (quoting Snyder v. Trepagnier, 
142 F.3d 791, 798 (5th Cir. 1998)). 
75 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 76 of 110
Further, the Fifth Circuit has โexplained that a policymaker who defends conduct that is 
later  shown  to  be  unlawful  does  not  necessarily  incur  liability  on  behalf  of  the 
municipality.โ Id. (citing Coon v. Ledbetter, 780 F.2d 1158, 1161โ62 (5th Cir. 1986)); Zarnow v. 
City of Wichita Falls, 614 F.3d 161, 169 (5th Cir. 2010) (โGood faith statements made in defending 
complaints against municipal employees do not demonstrate ratification.โ). 
In Peterson, the Fifth Circuit explained: 
In City of St. Louis v. Praprotnik, a case on which [plaintiff] relies 
[and which is the basis of ratification liability], the Supreme Court 
emphasized that โ[s]imply going along with discretionary decisions 
made by one's subordinates, however, is not a delegation to them of 
the authority to make policy. . . .โ [485 U.S. 112, 130 (1988)]. 
Additionally,  โthe  mere  failure  to  investigate  the  basis  of  a 
subordinate's  discretionary  decisions  does  not  amount  to  a 
delegation of policymaking authority. . . .โ Id. See also Kibbe v. City 
of Springfield, 777 F.2d 801, 809 n.7 (1st Cir. 1985) (โThe [district] 
court suggested that the City had ratified defendant Perry's action by

from which a jury properly could infer municipal policy.โ). 
 
588 F.3d at 848 n.2. See also Milam v. City of San Antonio, 113 F. App'x 622, 627 (5th Cir. 2004) 
(quoting to the same propositions from Praprotnik and explaining that โ[s]uch limitations on 
municipal liability are necessary to prevent the ratification theory from becoming a theory 
of respondeat superior, which theory Monell does not countenanceโ). Furthermore, the Fifth 
Circuit has held that โ[i]t is nearly impossible to impute lax disciplinary policy to [a governmental 
entity] without showing a pattern of abuses that transcends the error made in a single case.โ Quinn

the district court's dismissal of the plaintiff's excessive force claim against a police department).

b.  Analysis 
Again, Plaintiffs have strong evidence against the City on these claims.  This includes the 
preprinted affidavits themselves (some, relevant here, executed by officers without personal 
knowledge, and some, also relevant here, executed by officers who say they did not sign the 
affidavits), (see PRDSMF ยถยถ 26โ27, Doc. 309-1 at 7); the application of the Civil Disorder Policy 
for content-based reasons, (Rule 30(b)(6) Dep. 28:2โ29:3, Doc. 292-25); and the fact that it was 
โBRPD policy that the arrest team should not stop and have a conversation with the processing 
teamโ and that โ[t]hey should simply hand off the arrestee and return to the front lines[,]โ (id. at 
74:12โ17).  Considering all of this, a reasonable jury could easily find the City liable. 
However, when considering the evidence in a light most favorable to the City and drawing 
reasonable inferences in its favor (as the Court must do on Plaintiffsโ motion), for similar reasons 
cataloged aboveโthe threat of the interstate being overrun, thereby creating a danger to both the 
protesters and the public and obstruction of traffic; the concern for officer safety (as reflected by 
the thrown water bottles); and the considerable evidence of Plaintiffs being in the street after 
numerous  orders  to  disperse,  given  throughout  their  demonstration,  the  Court  finds  that  a 
reasonable jury could conclude that the City was not deliberately indifferent so as to subject it to 
Monell liability.  That is, the Court cannot say that Plaintiffs have established they are entitled to 
relief โbeyond peradventureโ or โbeyond doubt.โ  See Fontenot, 780 F.2d at 1194.   
Further, a reasonable jury could find, when looking at the facts from the Defendantsโ 
perspective, that this is not the sort of โextreme factual situation[]โ that satisfies the requirements 
for ratification. See Snyder, 142 F.3d at 798 (finding that the shooting of a fleeing suspect in the 
back โhardly [rose] toโ such a level, โparticularly given the absence of evidence suggesting a 
culture of recklessness in the NOPDโ). Cf. Grandstaff v. City of Borger, 767 F.2d 161 (5th 
77 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 78 of 110
Cir.1985) (finding ratification after officers โpouredโ gunfire onto a vehicle and killed innocent 
occupant).  This is particularly true given the facts that (1) the mere failure to investigate does not 
generally give rise to liability for ratification, see Peterson, 588 F.3d at 848 n.2; (2) โ[i]t is nearly 
impossible to impute lax disciplinary policy to [a governmental entity] without showing a pattern 
of abuses that transcends the error made in a single case,โ Quinn, 863 F.3d at 365, a showing which 
has not been made here; and (3) โit is hard to see how a policymaker's ineffectual or nonexistent 
response to an incident, which occurs well after the fact of the constitutional deprivation, could 
have caused the deprivation.โ Milam, 113 F. Appโx at 628 (cleaned up). 
Ultimately, reasonable minds could differ on the Cityโs liability for these claims, and that 
is exactly why the jury must decide it.   Consequently, Plaintiffsโ motion will be denied.

2. Applicable Law 
 โ[T]he police can stop and briefly detain a person for investigative purposes if the officer 
has a reasonable suspicion supported by articulable facts that criminal activity โmay be afootโ . . . 
โ Turner, 848 F.3d at 690 (quoting United States v. Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1, 7 (1989) (quoting Terry 
v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 30 (1968))). โThis type of stop is also known as a โTerry stop.โ โ Id. at 690 
n.54.  
 โThe Supreme Court has said repeatedly that when determining whether officers had 
reasonable suspicion, courts must look at the totality of the circumstances of each case to see 
whether  the  detaining  officer  has  a  particularized  and  objective  basis  for  suspecting  legal 
wrongdoing.โ Id. at 690โ91 (cleaned up).  Courts consider only the โinformation available to the 
officer[s] at the time of the decision to stop a person.โ Id. at 691 (citations omitted).  Further, โit 
is appropriate for the police to take into account the location of the suspicious conduct and the 
degree of the potential danger being investigated. What is not suspicious in one location may be 
highly suspicious in another.โ Id. at 692 (cleaned up).  โFinally, the Supreme Court has emphasized 
that courts must allow law enforcement officers to draw on their own experience and specialized 
training to make inferences from and deductions about the cumulative information available to 
them that โmight well elude an untrained person.โ United States v. Brigham, 382 F.3d 500, 507 
(5th Cir. 2004) (en banc) (cleaned up). But, โin determining whether the officer acted reasonably 
in such circumstances, due weight must be given, not to his inchoate and unparticularized 
suspicion or โhunch,โ but to the specific reasonable inferences which he is entitled to draw from 
the facts in light of his experience.โ  Terry, 392 U.S. at 27. 
The Court must โconsider each of [the relevant] factors in turnโ and โconsider whether 
these factors constitute specific and articulable facts which, when considered along with whatever 
79 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 80 of 110
reasonable inferences may be drawn from them, would allow a reasonable person to suspect that 
[the plaintiffs were] engaging in illegal activity.โ United States v. Lopez-Moreno, 420 F.3d 420, 
433  (5th  Cir.  2005)  (citation  omitted).  The  Court  must  โpay  heed  to  the  Supreme  Court's 
admonition not to treat each factor in isolation, but rather to give due regard to the totality of the 
circumstances.โ Id. (citations omitted). 
Additionally, โ[o]ne . . . exception to the warrant requirement exists for searches incident 
to a lawful arrest.โ United States v. Ho, 94 F.3d 932, 935 (5th Cir. 1996) (citing United States v. 
Barlow, 17 F.3d 85, 89 (5th Cir. 1994)).  โA warrantless arrest must be based on probable cause.โ  
If an officer lacked probable cause, and if the arrest is invalid, that search is unlawful under the 
Fourth Amendment. See id.   
Further, the law โpermit[s] a reasonable search for weapons for the protection of the police 
officer, where he has reason to believe that he is dealing with an armed and dangerous individual, 
regardless of whether he has probable cause to arrest the individual for a crime.โ Terry, 392 U.S. 
at 27.  โThe officer need not be absolutely certain that the individual is armed; the issue is whether 
a reasonably prudent man in the circumstances would be warranted in the belief that his safety or 
that of others was in danger.โ Id.

1. Partiesโ Arguments 
Defendants next turn to the excessive force claims. (Doc. 307-1 at 16โ17.)  Defendants say

  Plaintiffs respond that they need only show more than de minimis injury, and they have

Plaintiffs also dispute Defendantsโ position that the LRAD was ineffective, as these devices โcan

and hearing loss and has been found to be a potential basis for an excessive force claim.โ (Id. at 
17.)  Plaintiffsโ expert opines that this device may have caused injury. (Id. at 18.)  
2. Applicable Law 
โTo prevail on an excessive force claim, a plaintiff must establish: โ(1) injury (2) which 
resulted directly and only from a use of force that was clearly excessive, and (3) the excessiveness 
of which was clearly unreasonable.โ โ Freeman v. Gore, 483 F.3d 404, 416 (5th Cir. 2007) (Dennis, 
J.) (quoting Tarver v. City of Edna, 410 F.3d 745, 751 (5th Cir. 2005)). โExcessive force claims 
81 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 82 of 110
are necessarily fact-intensive; whether the force used is โexcessiveโ or โunreasonableโ depends on 
โthe facts and circumstances of each particular case.โ โ Deville v. Marcantel, 567 F.3d 156, 167 
(5th Cir. 2009) (quoting Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386, 396 (1989), and citing Brosseau v. 
Haugen, 543 U.S. 194, 201 (2004) (observing that this โarea is one in which the result depends 
very much on the facts of each caseโ)). โFactors to consider include โthe severity of the crime at 
issue, whether the suspect poses an immediate threat to the safety of the officers or others, and 
whether  he  is  actively  resisting  arrest  or  attempting  to  evade  arrest  by  flight.โ 
โ Id. (quoting Graham, 490 U.S. at 396). โThis list is not exclusive, however, and the Court may 
examine the totality of the circumstances.โ Drumgole v. Frumveller, No. 14-2827, 2015 WL 
2250134, at *8 (E.D. La. May 13, 2015). 
As  to  the  first  prong,  โthe  plaintiff's  asserted  injury  must  be  more  than de 
minimis.โ Freeman, 483 F.3d at 416 (citing Glenn v. City of Tyler, 242 F.3d 307, 314 (5th Cir. 
2001).  โThe  determination  of  whether  a  plaintiff's  alleged  injury  is  sufficient  to  support 
an excessive force claim is context-dependent and is โdirectly related to the amount of force that 
is constitutionally permissible under the circumstances.โ โ Id. at 416โ17 (quoting Ikerd v. Blair, 
101 F.3d 430, 435 (5th Cir. 1996) and citing Williams v. Bramer, 180 F.3d 699, 703 (5th Cir. 1999) 
(โIn determining whether an injury caused by excessive force is more than de minimis, we look to 
the context in which that force was deployed.โ)). โAlthough a showing of โsignificant injuryโ is no 
longer required in the context of an excessive force claim, [the Fifth Circuit] do[es] require a 
plaintiff asserting an excessive force claim to have โsuffered at least some form of injury.โ โ Glenn, 
242 F.3d at 314 (quoting Williams v. Bramer, 180 F.3d 699, 703 (5th Cir. 1999)); see also Keele 
v. Leyva, 69 F. App'x 659, 2003 WL 21356063, at *1 (5th Cir. 2003) (unpublished) (per curiam) 
(โThe injury must be more than a de minimis physical injury, but need not be significant or 
82

serious.โ (citing Gomez v. Chandler, 163 F.3d 921, 924 (5th Cir. 1999)). Elaborating on this, the 
Fifth Circuit said recently: 
โ[A]lthough a de minimis injury is not cognizable, the extent of 
injury necessary to satisfy the injury requirement is โdirectly related 
to the amount of force that is constitutionally permissible under the 
circumstances.โ โ Brown v. Lynch, 524 Fed. Appx. 69, 79 (5th Cir. 
2013) (quoting Ikerd v. Blair, 101 F.3d 430, 434โ35 (5th Cir. 
1996)). โAny force found to be objectively unreasonable necessarily 
exceeds  the  de  minimis  threshold,  and,  conversely,  objectively 
reasonable  force  will  result  in  de  minimis  injuries  only.โ  Id. 
(emphasis  added)  (footnote  omitted).  Consequently,  โonly  one 
inquiry is required to determine whether an officer used excessive 
force in violation of the Fourth Amendment.โ Ikerd, 101 F.3d at 434 
n.9. In short, โas long as a plaintiff has suffered โsome injury,โ even 
relatively insignificant injuries and purely psychological injuries 
will prove cognizable when resulting from an officer's unreasonably 
excessive force.โ Brown, 524 Fed. Appx. at 79 (footnotes omitted) 
(quoting Ikerd, 101 F.3d at 434). 
 
Alexander v. City of Round Rock, 854 F.3d 298, 309 (5th Cir. 2017). 
  As to the second prongโthat the injury โresulted directly and only from a use of force that 
was clearly excessive,โ Freeman, 483 F.3d at 416โthe Fifth Circuit โdistinguish[es] between 
injuries resulting from excessive force and those resulting from the justified use of force.โ Dunn 
v. Denk, 79 F.3d 401, 403 (5th Cir. 1996) (en banc) (citation omitted).  โA trier of the fact can 
compensate only for injury caused by the use of excessive force. There can be no award for injury 
caused by reasonable force.โ Id.  Thus, there is no bar to โrecovery for aggravation of preexisting 
injury caused by the use of excessive force.โ Id.  
3. Analysis  
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny Defendantsโ motion.  The heart 
of this motion is that (1) Plaintiffs did not suffer sufficient injury and (2) any injury was not caused 
by the police response.

But Defendants readily concede in their recitation of Plaintiffsโ interrogatories that all 
Plaintiffs suffered some emotional stress and trauma arising from the incident, as reflected in the 
operative complaint. (See Doc. 307-1 at 5โ9.)  And, again, โAny force found to be objectively 
unreasonable necessarily exceeds the de minimis threshold. . . [A]s long as a plaintiff has suffered 
โsome injury,โ even relatively insignificant injuries and purely psychological injuries will prove 
cognizable when resulting from an officer's unreasonably excessive force.โ Alexander, 854 F.3d 
at 309 (cleaned up).  Thus, the key question is whether Plaintiffs suffered objectively unreasonable 
force. 
A reasonable jury could find that they did.  Again, the Court must consider the totality of 
the circumstances in evaluating whether force was excessive, including โthe severity of the crime 
at issue, whether the suspect poses an immediate threat to the safety of the officers or others, and 
whether he is actively resisting arrest or attempting to evade arrest by flight.โ Deville, 567 F.3d at 
167 (cleaned up).  Here, the crimes were all non-violent misdemeanors, and the City has conceded 
through Plaintiffsโ chart (cited numerous times above) that no Plaintiff engaged in any act of 
violence.  Thus, questions of fact preclude summary judgment.

H. Failure to Intervene 
1. Partiesโ Arguments 
Defendants next attack the failure to intervene claims.  (Doc. 307-1 at 17.)  Defendants say 
that there was no First Amendment violation and therefore no duty to intervene. (Id. at 18.)  
Further, the searches, seizures, and arrests were also supported by probable cause. (Id)  Finally, 
the officers were trained in their duty to intervene. (Id.) 
  Plaintiffs  respond  that  โDefendants  argue  only  that  there  were  no  underlying  legal 
violations for officers to intervene against.โ (Doc. 309 at 18.)  โBut as described above, in 
Plaintiffsโ Motion for Summary Judgment, and in both expert reports, there is abundant evidence 
of Defendantsโ constitutional violations.โ (Id.)   
2. Applicable Law 
โ[A]n officer who is present at the scene and does not take reasonable measures to protect 
a suspect from another officer's use of excessive force may be liable under section 1983.โ Hale v. 
Townley, 45 F.3d 914, 919 (5th Cir. 1995) (citations omitted). โ[A]n officer may be liable under ยง 
1983 under [this] theory of bystander liability where the officer โ(1) knows that a fellow officer is 
violating an individual's constitutional rights; (2) has a reasonable opportunity to prevent the harm; 
and (3) chooses not to act.โ โ Whitley v. Hanna, 726 F.3d 631, 646 (5th Cir. 2013) (citations 
omitted).  
87 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 88 of 110
A Plaintiff must establish that the officer โknows that a fellow officer is violating an 
individualโs constitutional rights,โ and this logically requires that the officer observe the violation.  
See McDonald v. McClelland, 779 F. App'x 222, 226 (5th Cir. 2019) (per curiam) (finding that 
plaintiffโs bystander liability claim failed as a matter of law because โthe uncontroverted evidence 
[was] that none of the defendant officers saw any other officer kick [the plaintiff]โ and because 
โ[b]ystander liability cannot attach if the officer did not know about and acquiesce in the 
constitutional violation.โ (citing Whitley, 726 F.3d at 647)); Nowell v. Acadian Ambulance Serv., 
147 F. Supp. 2d 495, 507 (W.D. La. 2001) (concluding that summary judgment was properly 
granted with respect to the bystander claim because โthere is simply no evidence supporting 
plaintiff's claim that either defendant used excessive force on plaintiff, observed the complained 
use of excessive force or allowed plaintiff to be subjected to the use of excessive force, nor is there 
any evidence that [the officers] had any opportunity to take steps to prevent the alleged use of 
force, or to intervene to stop it.โ), aff'd, 390 F. App'x 305 (5th Cir. 2010).   
  Similarly, โliability will not attach where an officer is not present at the scene of the 
constitutional violation.โ Whitley, 726 F.3d at 646 (citations omitted).  However, โ[m]ere presence 
at the scene of the alleged use of excessive force, without more, does not give rise to bystander 
liability.โ Vasquez v. Chacon, No. 08-2046, 2009 WL 2169017, at *6 (N.D. Tex. July 20, 2009) 
(citing Nowell, 147 F. Supp. 2d at 507); see also Brown v. Wilkinson Cty. Sheriff Dep't, 742 F. 
App'x 883, 884 (5th Cir. 2018) (per curiam) (โ[plaintiff] concedes that he was harmed by three 
inmates and that an officerโs mere presence, without more, does not give rise to a bystander liability 
claim.โ); Garrett v. Crawford, No. 15-261, 2016 WL 843391, at *9 (W.D. Tex. Mar. 1, 2016) 
(โSimply being present at the scene of the alleged use of excessive force, without more, does not 
give rise to a cognizable claim for failure to intervene.โ (citing Vasquez, 2009 WL 2169017, at 
88 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 89 of 110
*6)); Montgomery v. Hollins, No. 18-1954, 2019 WL 2424053, at *3 (N.D. Tex. May 8, 2019) 
(โan officerโs โmere presence at the scene, without more, does not by some mysterious alchemy 
render him legally responsible under section 1983 for the actions of a fellow officer.โ โ (quoting 
Calvi v. Knox Cty., 470 F.3d 422, 428 & n.3 (1st Cir. 2006), report and recommendation adopted, 
No. 18-1954, 2019 WL 2422493 (N.D. Tex. June 10, 2019)).  The officer must have a โreasonable 
opportunity to realize the excessive nature of the force and to intervene to stop it.โ See Hale, 45 
F.3d at 919; Nowell, 147 F. Supp. 2d at 507 (same); Vasquez, 2009 WL 2169017, at *6 (same) 
(citing Hale, supra; Nowell, supra); see also Garrett, 2016 WL 843391, at *9 (describing this as 
a โnecessary inquiry in a failure to intervene claimโ (citing Hale, supra)). 
โIn resolving whether a plaintiff has sufficiently alleged a bystander liability claim we also 
consider whether an officer โacquiesce[d] inโ the alleged constitutional violation.โ Whitley, 726 
F.3d at 647 (citations omitted); see also Garrett, 2016 WL 843391, at *9 (same, citing Whitley).  
As one Court observed; 
In evaluating whether an officer took reasonable measures to protect 
a suspect, courts have considered both the duration of the alleged 
use of excessive force by other officers and the location of the 
suspect  relative  to  the  officer  against  which  a  claimant  seeks 
bystander liability. See Morris v. Pierce, 2008 WL 4287967, at *7 
(W.D.  La.  Sep.  17,  2008)  (no  bystander  liability  because  no 
summary judgment evidence to suggest that officer had a reasonable 
opportunity to intervene in a struggle that lasted 10โ15 seconds); 
Gilbert v. French, 2008 WL 394222, at *27 (S.D. Tex. Feb. 12, 
2008)  (no  indication  that  officers  had  time  to  prevent  use  of 
excessive force that occurred over the span of a few seconds); 
Haggerty v. Texas Southern Univ., 2005 WL 2030866, at *4 (S.D. 
Tex. Aug. 22, 2005) (no bystander liability because officer was 
several  yards  away  and  did  not  use  any  force  on  suspect); 
Paternostro  v.  Crescent  City  Connection  Police,  2002  WL 
34476319, at *11 (E.D. La. Apr. 2, 2002) (summary judgment 
evidence did not show that officer was in a location from which he 
could have had a realistic opportunity to prevent the violations of 
another officer).

Vasquez, 2009 WL 2169017, at *6; see also Garrett, 2016 WL 843391, at *9 (โIn making the 
determination of whether or not an officer acquiesced to the excessive force, courts consider the 
duration of the alleged use of force and the location of the suspect in relationship to the observing

16 (N.D. Tex. Nov. 6, 2014), appeal dismissed sub nom. Malone v. Tidwell, 615 F. App'x 189 (5th

reasonable inferences that may be drawn from those facts.โ Montgomery, 2019 WL 2424053, at 
*4 (citing Garrett, 2016 WL 843391, at *9โ10). 
3. Analysis 
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny Defendants relief.  The Court 
agrees with Plaintiffsโ assessment: the sole basis for Defendantsโ motion is that there is no 
underlying constitutional violation.9  But this Court has already concluded that there are numerous 
questions of fact on each of Plaintiffsโ federal claims.  As a result, Defendantsโ motion on this 
issue will be denied. 
I.  Civil Conspiracy 
1. Partiesโ Arguments 
Defendants next attack the conspiracy claims. (Doc. 307-1 at 18โ19.)  Defendants say 
Plaintiffsโ claims are โcolorful and hyperbolic, but there is an absence of proof[.]โ (Id at 19.)  
Further, J.D. Leach and former Chief Dabadie both testified that there was no conspiracy and that 
the โsupervisory levelโ defendants were disconnected from the events on the ground. (Id.)  โThe 
totality of the exhibits and deposition testimony show that this was ordinary police work, an effort

to keep peace on the streets of the city, that the plaintiffs were ordered to disperse and refused to

Plaintiffs respond, โDefendants argue that Plaintiffsโ civil conspiracy claims should be 
dismissed because two Defendants say there was no conspiracy. Two Defendantsโ contentions are

the meetings in the days leading up to the protest to coordinate a response; (2) Defendantsโ decision 
to use the Civil Disorder Policy which mandated disbursal; (3) the use of Affidavits of Probable

2. Applicable Law 
โA conspiracy may be charged under section 1983 as the legal mechanism through which 
to impose liability on all of the defendants without regard to who committed the particular act.โ 
Hale v. Townley, 45 F.3d 914, 920 (5th Cir. 1995) (cleaned up).  โTo prevail on a conspiracy claim 
under ยง 1983, the plaintiffs must show (1) the existence of a conspiracy involving state action and 
(2) a deprivation of their civil rights in furtherance of the conspiracy.โ Plaisance v. Reese, 353 F. 
Supp. 2d 735, 738 (E.D. La. 2004). 
As to the first, plaintiff must bring forward โfacts tending to show that the defendants 
entered into an agreement to deprive him of his [rights].โ Leggett v. Williams, 277 F. App'x 498, 
91 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 92 of 110
501 (5th Cir. 2008).  โ[A] conspiracy may be proved by circumstantial evidence.โ Mack v. Newton, 
737 F.2d 1343, 1350 (5th Cir. 1984) (citations omitted).  Indeed,  
Since conspiracies . . . are rarely evidenced by explicit agreements, 
the determination of whether a conspiracy existed almost inevitably 
rests on the inferences that may fairly be drawn from the behavior 
of the alleged conspirators. At a minimum, their actions, to support 
a finding of a conspiracy, must suggest a commitment to a common 
end. The circumstances must be such as to warrant a jury in finding 
that the conspirators had a unity of purpose or a common design and 
understanding, or a meeting of minds in an unlawful arrangement. 
 
Id. (cleaned up).   
But, โa mere scintilla of evidence is insufficient to present a question for the jury.โ Id. 
(cleaned up).  Unreasonable inferences, speculation, and conjecture are also inadequate. See id. 
โMere conclusory allegations of conspiracy cannot, absent reference to material facts, state a 
substantial claim of federal conspiracy under 42 U.S.C.A. ยง 1983.โ Leggett, 277 F. App'x at 501 
(citing Hale v. Harney, 786 F.2d 688, 690 (5th Cir. 1986) (internal quotation marks omitted)). 
As to the second, โa conspiracy claim is not actionable without an actual violation of 
section 1983.โ Hale, 45 F.3d at 920.  Thus, if all members of the conspiracy are entitled to qualified 
immunity on the underlying constitutional violation, then a โconspiracy claim is not actionable.โ 
Id. 
28 U.S.C. ยง 1985(3), entitled โDepriving Persons of Rights or Privileges,โ provides: 
If two or more persons in any State or Territory conspire . . .  for the 
purpose of depriving, either directly or indirectly, any person or 
class of persons of the equal protection of the laws, or of equal 
privileges and immunities under the laws; . . .  in any case of 
conspiracy set forth in this section, if one or more persons engaged 
therein do, or cause to be done, any act in furtherance of the object 
of such conspiracy, whereby another is injured in his person or 
property, or deprived of having and exercising any right or privilege 
of a citizen of the United States, the party so injured or deprived may 
have an action for the recovery of damages occasioned by such 
injury or deprivation, against any one or more of the conspirators. 
92 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 93 of 110
 
  โSection 1985(3) prohibits conspiracies to deprive any person equal protection of the 
laws.โ  Body by Cook, Inc. v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins., 869 F.3d 381, 389 (5th Cir. 2017), cert. 
denied, 138 S. Ct. 1009 (2018), reh'g denied, No. 17-892, 2018 WL 1786091 (U.S. Apr. 16, 2018) 
(citing 42 U.S.C. ยง 1985(3); Lockett v. New Orleans City, 607 F.3d 992, 1002 (5th Cir. 2010)). To 
establish a claim under ยง 1985(3), a plaintiff must demonstrate โ(1) a conspiracy; (2) for the 
purpose of depriving a person of the equal protection of the laws; and (3) an act in furtherance of 
the conspiracy; (4) which causes injury to a person or a deprivation of any right or privilege of a 
citizen of the United States.โ โ Id. (quoting Lockett, 607 F.3d at 1002).   
โTo state a cognizable claim under ยง 1985(3), [Plaintiffs] must allege that (1) a racial or 
class-based discriminatory animus lay behind the conspiracy and (2) the conspiracy aimed to 
violate rights protected against private infringement.โ Horaist v. Doctor's Hosp. of Opelousas, 255 
F.3d 261, 270 (5th Cir. 2001).  โ โIn this circuit, [courts] require an allegation of a race-based 
conspiracyโ to present a claim under ยง 1985(3).โ Id. at 271 (citing Bryan v. City of Madison, 213 
F.3d 267, 276 (5th Cir. 2000)).  Plaintiffs must show โracial animus,โ or else their ยง 1985(3) claims 
fail. Id. (affirming dismissal of ยง 1985(3) claim on Rule 12(b)(6) grounds); see also Lockett, 607 
F.3d at 1002 (the ยง 1985(3) โconspiracy must also have a racially based animusโ).    
  Like ยง 1983 conspiracy claims, a party asserting a ยง 1985(3) claim must demonstrate โan 
agreement among the alleged co-conspirators.โ Body by Cook, 869 F.3d at 389 (citing Green v. 
State Bar of Tex., 27 F.3d 1083, 1089 (5th Cir. 1994)).  Plaintiffs must do so with specificity, and 
they may not rely on mere conclusory allegations. See Holdiness v. Stroud, 808 F.2d 417, 424 (5th 
Cir. 1987) (quoted with approval by Body by Cook, 869 F.3d at 389โ90).

3. Analysis 
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny Defendantsโ motion.  Again, 
questions of fact preclude summary judgment. 
Defendantsโ sole argument is that there is insufficient evidence of an agreement, but 
Plaintiffs submit proof from which the inference can be drawn that there was in fact a meeting of 
the minds.  Plaintiffs point to the Cityโs decision to use the Civil Disorder Policy because โit was 
a protest for them to speak out against perceived misconduct by the [BRPD.]โ  (Rule 30(b)(6) Dep. 
28:2โ24, Doc. 292-25.)  Plaintiffs also refer to the โBRPD policy to target identified leaders and 
agitators,โ  (id.  at  35:17โ19),  the  latter  of  which  are  defined  by  BRPD  to  mean  โPersons 
encouraging others to upset the status quo to further their cause,โ including those who โwant to 
see a major change in the politics of Baton Rouge.โ (Id. at 35:20โ36:3, 38:2โ13.)  Thus, the use of 
these policies reflects an agreement by BRPD leadership and officers in their response to the 
protest. 
This  agreement  is  further  demonstrated  by  the  fact  that  pre-printed  and  pre-drafted 
Affidavits of Probable Cause were used. (See, e.g., Doc. 307-5.)  These affidavits were also 
circulated by email, which shows a certain amount of coordination. (See Doc. 292-15.)  Again, the 
inference can be made from this fact that the response was coordinated and orchestrated. 
Finally, Defendantsโ agreement is perhaps shown best by the events leading up to the 
arrests.   Plaintiffs submit evidence that, after an hour at East and France, BRPD declared, โWhere 
you are standing is not good enough.โ (Myron Daniels Dep. 120:8โ10, Doc. 292-22; see also John 
Clary Dep. 91:7โ12, Doc. 292-19 (โQ. So you heard the leave now, leave now. Where you are 
standing is not good enough? A. Yes, sir. Q. So is that the dispersal order that you described? A. 
94 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 95 of 110
Yes, sir. . . . โ).)  Lieutenant Christopher Taylor also stated in response to an audio clip of David 
Wallace (one of the shift leads):  
 
Q. Just to repeat what is sounded to me like [Wallace] said, it was, 
You've got one of the leaders requesting to walk on the sidewalk 
past France. Someone else responds, It's too late. Then 10-9. Then 
responds, Too late. Everyone has violated.   Everyone is under 
arrest.  Those  who  can  safely  apprehend  violators  must  do  so. 
Primary targets are the white male, red hair, tie-dyed shirt, and 
everyone else who is violating, which is everybody out there. Does 
that sound about right? 
 
A. Yes, sir. 
 
(Christopher Taylor Dep. 144:4โ22, Doc. 292-21; see also id. at 61:19โ62:3 (on Wallaceโs role).)   
None of the above evidence constitutes direct proof of a conspiracy.  But, again, โa 
conspiracy may be proved by circumstantial evidence.โ Mack, 737 F.2d at 1350 (cleaned up).  
โSince conspiracies . . . are rarely evidenced by explicit agreements, the determination of whether 
a conspiracy existed almost inevitably rests on the inferences that may fairly be drawn from the 
behavior of the alleged conspirators.โ Id. (cleaned up).  Here, Plaintiffsโ submissions, detailed 
above, reflect a โcommitment to a common end,โ a โunity of purpose,โ and a โmeeting of minds 
in an unlawful arrangement.โ Id. (cleaned up).  
In sum, construing all of this evidence in a light most favorable to Plaintiffs and drawing 
reasonable inferences in their favor, a reasonable juror could find an agreement on the part of the 
City  and  BRPD  officers  to  deprive  Plaintiffs  of  their  constitutional  rights,  including  equal 
protection, by making mass arrests and suppressing speech without justification.  Accordingly, 
Defendantsโ motion will be denied.

V.  Discussion of State Law Claims 
A.  Louisiana Constitution 
   Defendants move to dismiss the Louisiana constitution claims to the same extent as the 
federal claims. (Doc. 307-1 at 20.)  Plaintiffs argue they should be denied for the same reasons 
they previously argued. (Doc. 309 at 20.)   
  In short, the Court agrees with the parties.  Under the Louisiana Constitution, โ[n]o law 
shall curtail or restrain the freedom of speech or of the press. Every person may speak, write, and 
publish his sentiments on any subject, but is responsible for abuse of that freedom.โ La. Const. art. 
I, ยง 7.  The Fifth Circuit has recognized that โLouisiana's constitutional protection of free speech 
mirrors that of the First Amendment, so separate determinations of the state and federal claims are 
unnecessary.โ Heaney v. Roberts, 846 F.3d 795, 802 n.2 (5th Cir. 2017). 
Likewise, โ[i]n Louisiana, the right to privacy ensures that โ[e]very person shall be secure 
in  his  person,  property,  communications,  houses,  papers,  and  effects  against  unreasonable 
searches, seizures, or invasions of privacy.โ โ Bagley v. Kolb, No. 19-10, 2021 WL 3376830, at 
*16 (W.D. La. Aug. 3, 2021) (quoting La. Const. art. I, ยง 5). โAlthough the Louisiana Supreme 
Court has not articulated a clear standard for state constitutional claims alleging excessive force, 
โLouisiana federal district courts have noted that principles embodied in the Fourth Amendment 
have been incorporated into Article I, Section 5 of the Louisiana Constitution.โ โ Id. (quoting 
Shepherd v. City of Shreveport, No. 14-2623, 2018 WL 1513679, at *10 (W.D. La. Mar. 27, 2018) 
(citing Todd v. City of Natchitoches, 238 F. Supp. 2d 793, 798โ99 (W.D. La. 2002))). Further the 
Western District has also โheld that absent more precise guidance from the Louisiana Supreme 
Court, the โFourth Amendment standards control the analysis of alleged infringements on the 
constitutional right to privacy.โ โ Id. (quoting Tucker v. City of Shreveport, No. 17-1485, 2019 WL 
96 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 97 of 110
961993, at *11 (W.D. La. Feb. 27, 2019), rev'd on other grounds, 998 F.3d 165 (5th Cir. 2021)).  
Thus, in Bagley, the Western District granted and denied summary judgment on plaintiffโs state 
law constitutional claims to the same extent as it did the federal claims. See id.  
  Accordingly, because the Court has denied summary judgment as to Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 
claims, the Court will likewise deny summary judgment as to the corresponding claims under the 
Louisiana Constitution. 
B.  IIED and NIED 
1. Partiesโ Arguments 
Defendants then turn to Plaintiffsโ intentional infliction of emotional distress (โIIEDโ) and

that โthe officers preparing the affidavits of probable cause believed at the time that they were

Defendants further contend, โSeveral plaintiffs have alleged brief counseling, and a few have 
claimed longer periods of counseling for emotional trauma, anxiety, and so forth, but few if any 
have tried to show any causation linking the supposed trauma and distress to the conduct of the

rather sought to clear the roadways. (Id.)  According to Defendants, their actions do not rise to the 
level of โextreme and outrageous,โ and it is not โatrocious and utterly intolerable in a civilized

Plaintiffs respond that โDefendants do not know much about Plaintiffsโ emotional injuries. 
That is because they declined to notice any Plaintiff for deposition.โ (Doc. 309 at 20.)  Only Raae 
Pollard was deposed, and BRPD asked her no questions. (Id.)  While Defendants concede that 
97 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 98 of 110
several Plaintiffs received therapy, โmost Plaintiffs have not yet testified or been deposed โ and so 
they have not had any opportunity to โshowโ causation.โ (Id. at 21.)  In any event, there is evidence

2. Applicable Law 
Under Louisiana law, Plaintiff must establish the following to recover for IIED: โ(1) that 
the conduct of the defendant was extreme and outrageous; (2) that the emotional distress suffered 
by the plaintiff was severe; and (3) that the defendant desired to inflict severe emotional distress 
or knew that severe emotional distress would be certain or substantially certain to result from his 
conduct.โ  White v. Monsanto Co., 585 So. 2d 1205, 1209 (La. 1991). 
As to the first  requirement, โ[t]he conduct must be so outrageous in character, and so 
extreme in degree, as to go beyond all possible bounds of decency, and to be regarded as atrocious 
and utterly intolerable in a civilized community.โ Id. โLiability does not extend to mere insults, 
indignities, threats, annoyances, petty oppressions, or other trivialities. Persons must necessarily 
be expected to be hardened to a certain amount of rough language, and to occasional acts that are 
definitely inconsiderate and unkind.โ Id.  
As to the second element, โ[t]he distress suffered must be such that no reasonable person 
could be expected to endure it. Liability arises only where the mental suffering or anguish is 
extreme.โ Id. at 1210 (citations omitted). 
As to the final prong, โ[l]iability can arise only where the actor desires to inflict severe 
emotional distress or where he knows that such distress is certain or substantially certain to result 
98 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 99 of 110
from his conduct.โ Id. (citation omitted).  โThe conduct must be intended or calculated to cause 
severe emotional distress and not just some lesser degree of fright, humiliation, embarrassment, 
worry, or the like.โ Id. 
As to the NIED claims, โ[g]enerally, a defendant will not be held liable under Louisiana 
law where its conduct is merely negligent and causes only emotional injury unaccompanied by 
physical injury.โ Molden v. Georgia Gulf Corp., 465 F. Supp. 2d 606, 614 (M.D. La. 2006) 
(citing Moresi v. State, Dept. of Wildlife and Fisheries, 567 So. 2d 1081, 1096 (La. 1990)). 
โIn Moresi, the Louisiana Supreme Court considered whether a plaintiff could recover for mental 
disturbances caused by a defendant's ordinary negligence when the mental disturbance was 
unaccompanied by physical injury, illness, or other physical consequences.โ Id. (citing Moresi, 
567 So. 2d at 1095). The Moresi โcourt refused to allow recovery for mental anguish absent a 
physical injury except in โspecial circumstances.โ โ Id. (quoting Moresi, 567 So. 2d at 1096). 
โTo date, the Louisiana courts have identified only four instances in which recovery is 
allowed for mental anguish without physical injury.โ Id. โThese instances all involve โthe especial 
likelihood of genuine and serious mental distress, arising from the special circumstances, which 
serve as a guarantee that the claim is not spurious.โ โ Id. (quoting Moresi, 567 So. 2d at 1096). 
While four categories are provided, the one relevant here is: 
A plaintiff may recover damages for a defendant's infliction of 
emotional  distress  based  on  a  separate  tort  involving  physical 
consequences to the person or property of the plaintiff, such as an 
assault or a battery, false imprisonment, trespass to land, nuisance 
or the invasion of the person's right to privacy. [Moresi, 567 So. 2d 
at 1095.] 
 
Id. at 614.10 
 
10 The other three categories are: 
 
99 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 100 of 110
โWhen a plaintiff does not fall into one of [these] four categories, the plaintiff must prove 
the โclaim is not spurious by showing a particular likelihood of genuine and serious mental distress 
arising from special circumstances.โ โ Id. (quoting Bonnette v. Conoco, Inc., 837 So. 2d 1219, 
1235 (2003)). โIf the plaintiff is unable to meet this standard, recovery for mental distress is not 
allowed absent physical injury.โ Id. 
3. Analysis 
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will grant the motion in part and deny it 
in part. Specifically, the Court will dismiss the IIED claims but finds that the NIED claims survive. 
As to the IIED claims, Plaintiffs complain that Defendants have not engaged in sufficient 
discovery to determine what injuries Plaintiffs suffered, but that is not their burden.  Again, โ[a] 
movant for summary judgment need not set forth evidence when the nonmovant bears the burden 
of persuasion at trial.โ Wease, 915 F.3d at 997 (citing Celotex, 477 U.S. at 323).  โThe moving 
party may meet its burden to demonstrate the absence of a genuine issue of material fact by 
pointing out that the record contains no support for the non-moving party's claim.โ Id. (citation 
omitted).  Thus, Defendants did not need to engage in discovery concerning Plaintiffsโ injuries; 
 
A defendant's intentional infliction of emotional distress will also support an 
award for mental anguish damages. [White, 585 So. 2d 1205.] 
 
Furthermore, when the plaintiff is a direct participant in the accident causing the 
emotional injury, and the defendant owes a direct, specific statutory duty to the 
plaintiff to refrain from the specific conduct that causes the accident, damages for 
the infliction of emotional distress may be awarded, even absent physical injury. 
[Clomon v. Monroe City School Board, 572 So. 2d 571, 586 (La. 1990); Guillory 
v. Arceneaux, 580 So. 2d 990 (La. App. 3 Cir. 1991).] 
 
Finally, a bystander may recover an award for infliction of emotional distress 
where the bystander either views the accident or injury causing event or comes 
upon the accident before a substantial change. [Lejeune v. Rayne Branch Hospital, 
556 So. 2d 559, 570 (La. 1990). See also La. Civ. Code art. 2315.6 (codifying 
Lejeune). 
 
Molden, 465 F. Supp. 2d at 614โ15. 
100 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 101 of 110
rather, it was incumbent on Plaintiffs to bring forward summary judgment evidence showing there 
is a genuine issue for trial. See Matsushita Elec. Indus., 475 U.S. at 586โ87.  
Plaintiffs have largely failed to do so.  Elsewhere in their brief, Plaintiffs rely on the 
operative complaint to describe Plaintiffsโ injuries, but that cannot defeat summary judgment.  See 
10A Mary Kay Kane, Federal Practice and Procedure (Wright & Miller) ยง 2722 (4th ed. 2022) 
(โBecause the summary-judgment motion is designed to pierce the formal allegations of the 
pleadings, it normally is not made or opposed on the basis of the pleadings alone.โ); see also 10A 
Mary Kay Kane, Federal Practice and Procedure (Wright & Miller) ยง 2739 (4th ed. 2022) (โRule 
56 was amended in 1963 to add language in what then was subdivision (e) that explicitly stated 
that an opposing party could not rest upon mere allegations or denials in its pleading. . . . Thus, the 
practice prescribed by the amendment now is applied throughout the federal courts[.]โ); 1963 
Advisory Committee Note to Rule 56(e) (โThe very mission of the summary judgment procedure 
is to pierce the pleadings and to assess the proof in order to see whether there is a genuine need for 
trial. The Third Circuit doctrine, which permit[ed] the pleadings themselves to stand in the way of 
granting an otherwise justified summary judgment, [wa]s incompatible with the basic purpose of 
the rule.โ (quoted with approval by Kane, supra, at ยง 2739)).  Further, Defendants have provided 
a description of interrogatory responses seeking information about medical treatment. (Doc. 307-
1 at 5โ9.)  But the Court has reviewed this material and finds that none of it reflects the kind of 
severe and extreme emotional damages required for an IIED claim. 
While Plaintiffs do submit evidence as to Raae Pollard, that testimony does not meet her 
burden.  Pollard stated that her emotional distress damages included โdepression, loss of appetite, 
weight loss, and social isolationโ as well as an effect on her willingness to participate in future 
protests or demonstrations. (Raae Pollard Dep. 38:19โ39:10, Doc. 298-18.)   But Pollard could not 
101 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 102 of 110
say whether these problems still affect her today. (Id.)   Even considering the evidence in a light 
most favorable to Plaintiff, the Court cannot say that  โ[t]he distress suffered [is] such that no 
reasonable person could be expected to endure itโ or that โthe mental suffering or anguish is 
extreme.โ See White, 585 So. 2d at 1210 (citations omitted). 
For all these reasons, the Court finds that Plaintiffs have not demonstrated a genuine issue 
of material fact on their IIED claims.  Consequently, they will be dismissed. 
However, the Court will deny the motion with respect to the NIED claims.  As stated above,  
 
A plaintiff may recover damages for a defendant's infliction of 
emotional  distress  based  on  a  separate  tort  involving  physical 
consequences to the person or property of the plaintiff, such as an 
assault or a battery, false imprisonment, trespass to land, nuisance 
or the invasion of the person's right to privacy.  
 
Molden, 465 F. Supp. 2d at 614 (citing Moresi, 567 So. 2d at 1095).  As established elsewhere in 
this ruling, Plaintiffs have viable claims for assault, battery, and false imprisonment. Therefore, 
Defendantsโ motion on this issue will be denied.  
C.  Assault and Battery 
1. Partiesโ Arguments 
As to the assault and battery claims, Defendants assert:  
Under the circumstances presented, where the officers have been 
pelted with bottles and stones, the large numbers of protesters whose 
status as armed or unarmed is unknown, the possibility of being 
separated and outnumbered in a physical conflict, and the officers 
not  using  weapons,  whether  lethal  or  non-lethal,  all  indicate  a 
reasonable use of force. 
 
(Doc. 307-1 at 23.)   
  Plaintiffs respond that there is only evidence of two bottles thrown and that nothing was 
thrown by Plaintiffs. (Doc. 309 at 21.)  Further, there is no evidence to suggest that the protesters 
were armed or that any officer believed them to be so. (Id.)  To the contrary, the pictures of 
102 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 103 of 110
Plaintiffs being arrested show them surrounded by law enforcement officers. (Id. at 21โ22.)  
Additionally, the โnature of the offenseโ was a non-violent misdemeanor, and Defendants did not 
know the โcharacter of the arresteeโ other than that they were protesters. (Id. at 22.)  The โexigency 
of the momentโ is โhighly disputed.โ (Id.)  In sum, โ[w]hether the amount of force used in these 
arrests was reasonable is better left up to the finder of fact. Defendantsโ motion should be denied.โ 
(Id.) 
2. Applicable Law  
Louisiana Code of Criminal Procedure Article 220 provides, โA person shall submit 
peaceably to a lawful arrest. The person making a lawful arrest may use reasonable force to effect 
the arrest and detention, and also to overcome any resistance or threatened resistance of the person 
being arrested or detained.โ La. Code Crim. Proc. art. 220. โThe use of force by law enforcement 
officers must be tested by the โreasonable forceโ standard established by this article. The test 
precludes โclearly inappropriate force.โ โ Kyle v. City of New Orleans, 353 So. 2d 969, 972 (La. 
1977) (quoting La. Code Crim. Proc. art. 220, Official Revision Comment (b)).   
โThe use of force when necessary to make an arrest is a legitimate police function.โ 
Id.   โBut if the officers use unreasonable or excessive force, they and their employer are liable for 
any injuries which result.โ Id. (citations omitted); see also Penn v. St. Tammany Par. Sheriff's Off., 
2002-0893 (La. App. 1 Cir. 4/2/03), 843 So. 2d 1157, 1161 (stating that excessive force transforms 
authorized use of force into a battery).  โWhether the force used is reasonable depends upon the 
totality of the facts and circumstances in each case.โ Kyle, 353 So. 2d at 973.  โA court must 
evaluate the officersโ actions against those of ordinary, prudent, and reasonable men placed in the 
same position as the officers and with the same knowledge as the officers.โ Id. โThe degree of 
force employed is a factual issue.โ Id. (citations omitted). 
103 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 104 of 110
The Louisiana Supreme Court has explained further: 
 
Several factors to be considered in making this determination are the 
known character of the arrestee, the risks and dangers faced by the 
officers,  the  nature  of  the  offense  involved,  the  chance  of  the 
arrestee's escape  if the  particular means  are not employed, the 
existence of alternative methods of arrest, the physical size, strength, 
and weaponry of the officers as compared to the arrestee, and the 
exigencies of the moment. 
 
Kyle, 353 So. 2d at 973 (citations omitted). 
  Ultimately, โexcessive force claims under both federal and Louisiana law turn on whether 
the use of force was objectively reasonable given the totality of the circumstances. This has been 
widely recognized by [the Fifth Circuit], Louisiana federal district courts, and the Louisiana 
Supreme Court.โ Shepherd on behalf of Est. of Shepherd v. City of Shreveport, 920 F.3d 278, 286 
(5th Cir. 2019) (collecting cases).  
3. Analysis 
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny Defendantsโ motion, largely 
for the same reasons the federal excessive force claims survive. In short, questions of fact preclude 
summary judgment. 
Construing the evidence in a light most favorable to Plaintiffs and drawing reasonable 
inferences in their favor, a reasonable jury could easily conclude that the force used in this case 
was excessive.  Again, the officerโs vulnerability to the protesters is in question, given Defendantsโ 
body armor, armored vehicle, LRAD, pistols, patrol rifles, and the ability to deploy tear gas, (see 
Rule 30(b)(6) Dep. 120:1โ5, 126:11โ127:2,  128:10โ17, 214:8โ10, Doc. 292-25), in addition to 
their undercover operative, helicopter, and โfixed wing airplaneโ for overhead footage, (id. at 
215:20โ21, 222:6โ8).  All of this contrasts strongly to the extensive evidence, discussed above, 
that these protests were peaceful. (See, e.g., Kraska Report, Doc. 309-3 at 6; Pusins Report, Doc. 
104 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 105 of 110
309-2 at 47.)  Further, each of the offenses at issue were minor misdemeanors, thereby decreasing 
the need for force.  The officers cannot complain of the arrestees escaping, as the officers (at least 
ostensibly) wanted the crowd to disperse.   
In sum, looking at the totality of the circumstances from the facts presented by Plaintiffs, 
a jury could find that the arresting officers employed โclearly inappropriate forceโ to the protesters.  
Consequently, Defendantsโ motion will be denied.   
D.  False Imprisonment 
Defendants incorporate their previous arguments about false imprisonment. (Doc. 307-1 at 
23.)  Plaintiffs do the same. (Doc. 309 at 22.)  
โUnder Louisiana law, โ[f]alse arrest and imprisonment occur when one arrests and 
restrains another against his will without a warrant or other statutory authority. Simply stated, it is 
restraint without color of legal authority.โ โ Elphage v. Gautreaux, 969 F. Supp. 2d 493, 514 (M.D. 
La. 2013) (quoting Kyle v. City of New Orleans, 353 So. 2d 969, 971 (La. 1977)). โ[I]f police 
officers act pursuant to statutory authority in arresting and incarcerating a citizen, they are not 
liable for damages for false arrest and imprisonment.โ Id. (quoting Kyle, 353 So. 2d at 971). See 
also La. Code Crim. Proc. arts. 213 (describing circumstances of warrantless arrest), 215.1 
(describing circumstances of Terry stop). 
  This Courtโs analysis to Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 false imprisonment and false arrest claims 
applies with equal force to the state law claims.  See Elphage, 969 F. Supp. 2d at 515 (citing 
Harrison v. State Through Dept. of Pub. Safety and Corr., 97-1086 (La. 12/1/98); 721 So. 2d 458, 
462โ63); O'Dwyer v. Nelson, 310 F. App'x 741, 745 n.4 (5th Cir. 2009) (finding that, because 
Fourth  Amendment  principles  underpin  Louisiana  law  relating  to  false  arrests,  the  Fourth 
Amendment inquiry  was applicable to both O'Dwyer's  federal  and state law  claims (citing 
105 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 106 of 110
Harrison, 721 So. 2d at 462โ63)). See also Curran v. Aleshire, 67 F. Supp. 3d 741, 754 (E.D. La. 
2014) (dismissing federal and state false arrest, false imprisonment, and malicious prosecution 
claims as Heck-barred).  Accordingly, for the same reasons highlighted above, the Court will deny 
Defendantsโ motion on the state law false imprisonment claims. 
E.  Malicious Prosecution 
Defendants urge that Plaintiffsโ malicious prosecution claim should be dismissed because 
there was probable cause to arrest Plaintiffs. (Doc. 307-1 at 23.)  Plaintiffs respond that, for the 
same reasons given earlier, there was no probable cause for the arrests, so Defendantsโ motion 
should be denied. (Doc. 309 at 23.) 
The elements of a Louisiana state law malicious prosecution claim are:  
(1) the commencement or continuance of an original criminal or 
civil  judicial  proceeding;  (2)  its  legal  causation  by  the  present 
defendant in the original proceeding; (3) its bona fide termination in 
favor of the present plaintiff; (4) the absence of probable cause for 
such proceeding; (5) the presence of malice therein; and (6) damage 
conforming to legal standards resulting to plaintiff. 
 
Lemoine v. Wolfe, 2014โ1546 (La. 3/17/15), 168 So. 3d 362, 367 (citation omitted).  Here, 
Defendants attack only the fourth requirement. 
Because this Court has already determined that a reasonable juror could find the absence 
of probable cause, Plaintiffs have created questions of fact on their malicious prosecution claims.  
Consequently, Defendantsโ motion will be denied.

Defendants next assert that they are entitled to summary judgment on the negligence claim. 
(Doc. 307-1 at 23โ24.) Defendants contend:

2. Applicable Law 
โThe duty-risk analysis  is  the  standard  negligence  analysis  employed  in  determining 
whether to impose liability underโ Article 2315. Lemann v. Essen Lane Daiquiris, Inc., 2005-1095 
(La. 3/10/06); 923 So.2d 627, 632โ33 (citing Mathieu v. Imperial Toy Corp., 94-0952 (La. 
11/30/94); 646 So. 2d. 318, 321). Under this analysis, a plaintiff must prove five separate elements: 
(1) the defendant had a duty to conform his conduct to a specific 
standard (the duty element); (2) the defendant's conduct failed to 
conform to the appropriate standard (the breach element); (3) the 
defendant's substandard conduct was a cause in fact of the plaintiff's 
107 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 108 of 110
injuries (the cause-in-fact element); (4) the defendant's substandard 
conduct was a legal cause of the plaintiff's injuries (the scope of 
liability or scope of protection element); and (5) the actual damages 
(the damages element). 
 
Id. at 633 (citing Fowler v. Roberts, 556 So. 2d 1, 4 (La. 1989), reh'g granted on other grounds 
and original opinion reinstated as supplemented, 556 So. 2d at 13 (La. 1990)). โA negative answer 
to  any  of  the  inquiries  of  the duty-risk analysis  results  in  a  determination  of  no 
liability.โ Id. (citing Mathieu, 646 So. 2d at 326). 
3. Analysis 
Having carefully considered the matter, the Court will deny the motion, for the reasons 
given by Plaintiffs.  Defendants seem to argue that they breached no duty and that, if they did, 
Plaintiffs suffered only nominal injuries.  As to the latter, the Court already determined in the 
excessive force section that Plaintiffs suffered some injury, even if they were minor.   
As to the breach element, there are simply too many questions of fact, detailed throughout 
this ruling, to find in favor of Defendants.  A reasonable jury could easily find that these 
Defendants failed to act as reasonably prudent officers under the circumstances.  Consequently, 
Defendantsโ motion will be denied.  
G. Vicarious Liability and Indemnity 
Defendants lastly seek dismissal of the vicarious liability and indemnity claims. (Doc. 307-
1 at 24โ25.)  Defendants argue that, because Plaintiffs cannot establish an underlying tort, there 
can be no respondent superior liability. (Id. at 25.)  As to indemnity, Defendants argue that 
Plaintiffsโ position echoes its vicarious liability claim. (Id.) 
  Plaintiffs respond that the sole basis for Defendantsโ argument on vicarious liability is the 
absence of an underlying tort. (Doc. 309 at 24.)  Since Plaintiffs have met their burden on the other 
claims, Defendantsโ motion should be denied here. (Id.)  Further, โDefendants do not offer any 
108 
 

Case 3:17-cv-00439-JWD-EWD     Document 347    07/14/22   Page 109 of 110
argument to find summary judgment on indemnity beyond claiming that it is a restatement of 
vicarious liability.โ (Id.)  
Turning to the law, โ[a]t common law, the Latin phrase respondeat superior (โlet the 
master answerโ) denotes the employerโs liability for the employeeโs tort committed in the course 
and scope of employment.โ 1 Frank L. Maraist, et al., Louisiana Tort Law ยง 13.02 (2021).  โThe 
foundation of respondeat superior is the employeeโs tort. Thus, where the employee was not guilty 
of a tort, the employer cannot be vicariously liable.โ Id.  โLouisiana Civil Code Article 2320 
codifies the concept, providing, in part:    [โ]Masters and employers are answerable for the damage 
occasioned by then-servants and overseers, in the exercise of the functions in which they are 
employed [.][โ] โ Id. 
As to the indemnity claim, the Court agrees with Plaintiffs; Defendantsโ position rests 
entirely on the lack of an underlying tort.  
For all of the above reasons, the Court finds that Plaintiffs have demonstrated questions of 
fact on nearly all of their claims.  Consequently, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss the vicarious 
liability and indemnity claims will be denied.
